12132111111122.content:
Eric's focus on the VIP room was broken as he could see two large bouncers heading his way from the side rooms, immediately he moved towards the dance floor in order to try and slow them down. They must've noticed that he was one of the only people in the room who wasn't drunk or high, even more so with his eyes lingering on the VIP entrance for too long. The cyborg fox quickly dashed through the dancers, but was surprised when two other bouncers gripped him from under his arms and the two hauled him out, lifting him up enough that his legs kicked the air. "You shouldn't have come here runt. This club is for those of us who are a little more established, not for snot-nosed kids." The bouncer on his left who in light was a brown bear grunted as he managed to hold the young fox in his grip, kicking the front door open as they forced him out to the street. "Time to get lost, or we'll teach you not to overstay your welcome on Miss Rouge's property."

         "You know... you have a point..." Eric managed to speak before he detached the bolt of his metal arm, slipping out of their grip before cracking the other bouncer in the head with his detached arm. He quickly snapped it back on before he slammed his robotic fist into the brown bear bouncer's head and the other bouncer's several times until they stopped getting up from the street. The fox took several breathes before he realized that all eyes were on him and the two bouncers groaning on the concrete, including a handful of bouncers that rushed out of the club to deal with him. Facing all of those threats at once made Eric turn tail and run as fast as he could away, knowing feel well he couldn't handle all of them and attempt to go inside without guns being pointed at his face. The chase between him and the bouncers went on for blocks as the handful of Rouge's trusted workers were well equipped with endurance and strength, something he only had a small tank for. Eric managed to duck out of harms way after losing their eye contact for the third time by climbing a gutter pipe up to the building's roof six stories up, gasping for breath as he couldn't believe how everything went sideways.

         He considered the brown bear's point about his failings, knowing full well that any more attempts to face Rouge as himself were gone unless he could magically talk to her without getting shot first. Eric sighed as he had an idea how to sneak in, involving a technique he learned under his old mentor the Thief Lord that changed his shape, but there were too many problems that could arise. First and foremost, he could not changed into anything beyond someone he had examined closely since he did not have the experience to change into a random form that he had to make himself without the whole thing falling away after 5 minutes. His mentor could change into anyone or things since he had perfected this ability over the course of several decades, while Eric had only a few years at best after working to learn this invaluable skill for his trade. Second, he had to pick someone who could get past the VIP doorway, but there were too many risks from what the two already knew and talked about that he had to know the hows and whats between them. If Eric stumbled into a conversation that involved a topic he didn't know, the ease of info accessed from his target would lessen and detection could happen.

         Eric then dug into his tool belt and pulled out a small square box before setting it on the ground. He tapped the top of it and watched it extend into a mirror for him to practice on, taking a breath as he decided on who he would test out first. His first thoughts were of his sister Jasmine, a white furred fox not unlike him and his brother Tails who he lost to Robotnik after he was re-caught most recently. Her form slowly appeared in the mirror in front of him as her tough girl look from when she was taken from him, a biker girl with the leather to show off. Jasmine wore a black biker vest with the words "Fallen Angels" on the back, cut up jeans that looked like she fell off her motorcycle at some point and shiny black leather boots when he saw her last, along with a knife sheath on her hip that was empty. Eric looked at his sister's form and slowly adjusted her age using the computer in his robotic arm for reference, knowing a preteen would be stopped on the way in the club, adjusting her to be 21 in case someone bothered to check her up. He shook his head at her outfit as it reminded him too much of her death, switching out her tough look for the white furred angel of his past, where she could look like a woman on her night out than a troublemaker for a bar fight. He gave her a small clean up where her leather went away in exchange for a formal turquoise dress, gold open toe pump heels and a pair of small gold earrings with turquoise stones, making her become what he hoped for her future. Eric however wanted to test his abilities against the mythology of humans, using Jasmine as his set piece, he formed what she would look like if she was human to push his skills to a new level. Jasmine's Mobian form slowly altered to fit what he considered a human version of her, from growing to 5'7 as humans were taller to the small features of her pale white skin. Jasmine grew blond hair and remained skinny as he couldn't force himself to make her shapely since he was becoming awkward with her image in front of him.

         The cyborg fox tried to pretend to be Jasmine as both human and Mobian, but he kept thinking of how his sister would react with him using her as his disguise so he quickly dissolved her shape to his own while he considered another option that began to form in front of the mirror. His shape turned to that of Xin, a red panda who did hits for the shadowy organization named Dusk, her short but slightly muscular form did her well in achieving her work. He couldn't help but put her form into a finely designed red formal dress that cost more than he could steal in a week along with her jade heels and a pair of her simple silver jet earrings that she was comfortable in for overt jobs since it was better than her black jumpsuit. If anyone could get into anywhere, it would be the killer with expensive tastes who was known for ending anyone who didn't give her what she wanted, something Rouge could respect. Eric also tested how his friend would look as a human, Xin turning into a young Korean woman who was 5'5 who shared her muscular yet feminine form, but grew dark brown hair that was shortly tied in a small bun for ease. He appreciated the forms she had since she was older than him and could easily go in any club that she wanted, but once he glanced towards the club, he had to reconsider. The whole street was on lock-down, with guards blocking access everywhere and a double set of bouncers at the doors who were frisking everyone who wanted in. Eric sighed as he couldn't show up as a known assassin to her club after he knocked heads, it would draw way too much attention and Xin was anything but the wrong type of attention.

         He thought deeply about what he could do with the situation he unfortunately put himself into and slowly came up with someone who Rouge couldn't afford to turn away, someone whom had connections with all collectors of valuable merchandise and someone who he could actually pull off. Eric slowly pushed out of his friend Xin's form and into her best friend Sarah, who was well known for being both cutthroat and quite the collector of well sought after items. Her appearance in the mirror reflected a orange fox much taller than Xin, more shapely but not exactly hourglass with her moderately formed breasts and behind, wearing a small black dress and small red orb earrings that she was known to wear, but an idea he had changed her outfit to a one-piece blue swimsuit with a white skirt around the waist. In his mind, Sarah was as cagey as she was smart, setting a meeting with Rouge would be weird if Sarah didn't have a plan and nothing like a dip in Rouge's rumored private pool would make the right balance. There would be no way to hide bugs to record them, no one else to be watching them and it set Rouge in the mindset that he would really be Sarah than a fake. Eric slowly mimed Sarah's walk and practiced how she moved her mouth and her expressions, until he felt like it was really Sarah who was glaring at him for messing with her body in the mirror instead of his reflection.

         With a slowly breath, he climbed down the pipe again and walked towards the club, fully focused on keeping his appearance consistent for the bouncers. At first Eric had to stand by while a bouncer frisked his form and gripped near places he shouldn't have, but eventually they let her into the main floor, which was more animated from his antics outside the club. The disguised fox moved through the crowd carefully until she reached the VIP door with the brown bear that wore the bruises from their last encounter on his face. "Name?" the bouncer asked as he looked her over, clearly wondering why this fox would wear a swimsuit to a dance club, but it gave Eric an advantage as he didn't know Sarah by sight.

"I am the Collector, I want a meeting with your boss in her private pool for a little talk. If Rouge doesn't come out, I walk and she loses on some business." Eric spoke with her traits, putting her hands on her hips and glaring at the bear until he put a claw to his ear and relayed the message, pausing as they waited for Rouge to respond.

The brown bear bouncer listened closely before he moved aside for Eric, his expression changing to respect and even apologetic to the small orange fox in front of him. " Sorry miss, go on in and keep straight until you see the sign. Someone will unlock the entrance for you and will lead you down."

"Whatever." Eric spoke with a bit of a bite as Sarah was not one for waiting around, but walked through with a sigh as he finally was on his way to see Rouge and get some answers.

1223.content:
Eric had just moved into the room toward the bar when he bumped his leg with a short but thin raccoon, making him look down. "Hey, watch where you..." Suddenly, his eyes lit up and he smiled like he hadn't for years. "Vex?! Is that you?"

The raccon slowly looked up and a hardened face slowly turned gleeful. "You old metalhead, come give me a hug." The voice was much different than an outsider would've guessed for such a short raccoon, as it was feminine even though the body looked mostly male like with no breasts to speak of and no feminine figure. Only a few in the past would've known this raccoon as Vex, though most would remember what a trickster she was and how their pockets were always lighter when she walked by. With her child-like size, she easily cleared crowds and remained mostly undetected and her flexibility and agility, she was a clear title of an acrobat with lean muscle covering her small body.

Both hugged each other, a little awkwardly as Eric had to knee down to hug her, but slowly made themselves to a table where Vex had a filled glass waiting with a bottle nearby. "So... years go by and not a message? I figured I was tough on you when we were little, but seriously?"

"Yeah, well, It's especially hard to send a message so far away without giving away yourself. Speaking of which, how was the far east? Did you bring back something other than your insightful options?" Eric grinned as Tex slowly chuckled before going into her bag and placing a tanto in front of them, letting Eric examine it. "Cool, this thing looks genuine. Bought it at the dollar store did you?"

"Ass." Vex grunted before she snatched the blade from his paws, holding it up to the candle on the table. "I got it from some rich kid who had it his family for some number of years. Bragging it was older than the Acorn empire! Figured I'd sell it to the boss or huck it at targets until it served some usefulness."

"Older than the Acorn empire... seems doubtful..." Eric commented as he looked at his old friend and started to get a bit more serious. "Have you heard from our friends?"

Vex fell quiet and put away the blade on her belt before answering. "Yeah." Vex then gulped what was in her glass and poured another, as if she needed to dull herself to tell anything.

"Care to share with the class?"

"Look..." Vex started to explain as she tried to touch Eric's hand, but saw his recoil quickly and felt sad about it. "Sarah is around, but she has a new name that she'd prefer you use, called the Collector. I don't know much about Beetle except he made a name of himself putting a 'Golden' in his name from some job he did. Zarran is some two-bit thug for some gang that will go nowhere and Xin... she disappeared again. This time we're all looking for a body, as sad as it is."

She watched Eric remain serious as he heard about his friends and recorded it into his memory, focusing on Sarah as he worried about her and her obsessions. He knew Beetle could take care of himself, as well as Xin as he didn't think she was gone completely, he had already given up on Zarran changing his ways so he just let it go. Slowly he took her glass and downed her drink before letting it slam on the table upside down. "Alright. We'll keep in contact, but I have somethings I want to do before my leash pulls me back to the fathead. Try to get everyone together, I have a favor to ask everyone as well as settle somethings. Take care Vex and keep your feet and nose to the ground."

Vex watched Eric stand up and leave and saw the weight of the world on his shoulders, bending him to all of his baggage he kept close at heart. She knew she had just remind him of their old baggage, but he seemed to walk it off well, which made her frown as he still kept to his word after all of this time. She drank the rest of her bottle and sighed as she had to get another to drown away a pit in her gut that had formed when he pulled away.

"Hey, toss me another bottle here, I'm too sober here!' She called out to the bartender who quickly tossed her another bottle, knowing it was better to give then bug one of the Thief Lord's star pupils for cash.

12232.content:
Only a few ever met the leader of the Thieves Guid, as this figure has been credited with thefts though impossible like the theft of King Acorn's crown many years ago and the theft of exotic treasures from around the world. Every place in the world has a bounty on capture, dead or alive, it matters little when they had an expensive bone to pick with him. However, even fewer have seen his face, as he always wore a hood and a mask outside of his base. Seven have seen his true identity, and only three have lived between them all, which held the highest trust between them and this legend of life.

Common courtesy was always expected, and even when Eric knew the Thief Lord to an almost personal level, he treated the man like his king above all. Eric owed his life to the Lord, after taking him in when no others would, training him as a son and teaching him how to change his perspectives on what mattered truely, Eric tried to hold to the creed of his master even when his programming tried to force him away. Yet some choices are hard to face, and Eric had made many bad decisions against his Lord.

Eric tried not to think hard on his past as he slowly knelt in front of a wooden desk with a figure in a rich green cloak sat. The mask the Lord wore was a usual one, a white clay made features of a hearty smile with wide eyes of ammusement, something he wore to fight talk of his old age. Slowly a hand was raised and Eric rose to meet his mentor and friend. "Greetings Lord."

"Those freedom fighters this morning were under our protection. " The Lord spoke in an exhausted voice, but full of an edge that hit Eric hard, as he knew his mentor disapproved of his night job."

" Lord... my puppet master has me under a tight lock, I need to give him something for the freedom to help you."

"At the cost of those poor people's freedom, no doubt." Eric looked away from his mentor and remained quiet as not to be rude, slowly returning his gaze to see his mentor, who sighed before he rose from his seat. "I understand you have no choice, with that program that makes you into his soldier, but we had people on the inside. Brothers and sisters, who are uncounted for because of you."

"Forgive me mentor. I am sorry." Eric lower his head and looked down from the man who gave him the ability to be free, despising his uncomfortable postion between friend and his most hated enemy.

"Your pity is pointless, you need to unshackle yourself from him, or you will continue to be a liability to your friends and to me." The Thief Lord moved himself to a poster on the wall, which held the rules everyone had to follow in order to remain in the Guild. "The leader of those Fighters spoke with me the other day."

"Sir?" Eric was surprised to hear of Sally's presence anywhere near the Guild as her personality profile held the idea of thievery to be completely ridiculous. Yet occasionally she would allow her members to be part of the Guild for the resource, people Eric knew well and knew to keep a blank face to.

"She continues to ask why we have not found a culprit to the number of her fighter bases capture, and the number of people who are caught from her side because of it. Even with our relationship, at some point I have to tell her something."

"I'll figure it out mentor, I always do." Eric stood and turned to face the door, before calling back to the Lord. "You can tell her who I am, you don't owe me anything."

To this, Eric heard a bit of a laugh, although it was quickly taken by coughs before his mentor's voice returned to him. "I could, but I'm not too good with turning on family, even when they are a pain in my ass. Goodbye Eric."

"Goodbye Mentor." Eric nodded with a smile before he headed out, knowing his other master was no doubt waiting impatiently to bark commands at him when he came 'home'. He hated that word when it came to the hole he had as a place in that tower, little more than a storage room turned empty. Feeling angry as he always did going back, he moved through the bar with purpose in his step, ignoring the eyes of the hooded stranger who watched him go through the door, before finishing his drink with a gulp.

124.content:
Downtown was one of the most balanced places in the whole city for people like Eric, where the corrupted aristocrat smoked along with a cutthroat loanshark and the rebels bumped shoulders with the machines. Normal citizens who were in constant fear that the next raid was the last, and where the vultures of society were the local men in charge. Not to say that Eric was on the moral high end, he had done his fair share of thieving with his friends in the Guild and even had the friendship of a master assassin who did hits for the Underworld. Yet even he knew he had not sunk so low as the thug beating a man to death in an alley he went by, he was close, but not there yet.

Eric employed a variety of ears and eyes in Downtown for himself, some with money and praise, others with his fist or a knife against their throats. He needed to know everything about his prey, the rebels who fought his sworn master, and the wiring in his own head. Eric hated the program and brainwashing he endured after being recovered from the Thieves Guild by Robotnik, it kept him in line worse than any beating he had taken. Plus it was forever in his head, until the day he died, he would serve every order from Robotnik. However he bided his time and soon the old man, as well as anyone who would hurt him, would die.

Not that he planned to wait until he died to be free of Robotnik. He almost had a plan how to get free of his Overlord program, but he did not know the safeguards in place and hoped he did not cut off his life line in the process. He needed an intense hacker and tech genius just to make it to a diagnosis, which was on his short list. He knew of a hacker with the credit to his bragging not too far away, but he was always resistant on matters that related to charity. Eric also knew of several in the Freedom Fighters by their IP addresses and the strength of their attacks on Robotnik, as well as shadow-organizations with low net footprints, but they would be more likely to kill him where he stood then help him.

In the end though, he figured for once he could just rest and not cause trouble or be in trouble by visiting some old tourist spots he knew of before Robotnik took control. So he headed toward an old landmark that used to bring him joy, the memorial garden to the deceased soldiers from the Last Great War. He and his brother Miles had played their countless times as their father gave his respect to their memory. Eric figured his dad would approve, and Eric could also give his respects to his dad, whom was killed along with his mother and brother the day he escaped Robotnik. The memory still hurt him, and his robot side always tried to keep him from losing himself in grief. He however was on his guard, as even in his age, he had enemies in shadows and people looking for him.

Eric stood in front of the bronze plaque commemorating each of the soldiers names and he felt a moment of empathy for the families who shared his pain of never seeing their loved ones again. But it was gone as soon as it came as Eric dipped his head and knelt at the plaque, the garden now barren as he felt rage consume him, tears running down his flesh cheek. The memories that anchored him to this place dug a hole in his heart. They would never happen again, no longer would he see his mother's smile, no longer would he hear his father's voice.

He would be alone, only to rely on himself for survival.

To call his place where he slept "a room" was a stretch, as it was barely enough space for the mattress on the floor and Eric at the same time. He had to take off the door to what he called "the box" in order to fit his own things inside. Yet he made holes in the wall where he stored his personal things, as a form of shelves built into the wall. It was his home though, and no one dared bother him while he was there, mostly since his room was at the top of the tower near his old cell.

Eric sat on his mattress, looking through his arm's interface while a cord that hung from the ceiling charged him up. His battery was still unable to keep a charge for too long, yet he didn't dare try to replace it as it was nested right by his heart, so he stuck to power cords. He glanced at profiles of his targets, each had a number for their priority, yet Sally Acorn was always enemy number 1. Eric often wondered what a different life Sally must be in after her father was wiped from the throne, now somewhere without AC, barking orders to her friends while squatting in a hut. More than most, he wondered why the rebels kept fighting. Somehow after everything they lost, they still had the strength to keep going. It was admirable, if misguided.

His time alone was interupted as a furry wolf in skull armour walked up to his spot, his ugly boots resting in Eric's sight before he looked up. "Get up, we have work to do."

"What work Sleet? I just took down a whole stealth base, the least I get is a few days off."

Sleet frown and kicked Eric's bed impatiently, crossing his arms stubbornly. "I don't care you idiot, Robotnik called us both in, get off your behind and we can get it finished quickly." He tapped his foot on the floor until Eric got up and unplugged himself, shoving the cyborg fox down the hall as he didn't care to drag this out. Eric thought that something big must've happened to call him back in, possibly some new intel or Sonic out on the loose where he would help Sleet and Dingo get him. Yet nothing brought up his mood, as he really didn't have anyone to make him happy in his slice of paradise since he couldn't save his family.

Eric answered with a toothy grin that made the salon owner a bit nervous, pausing only to read the badge on the frog's collared shirt.
