13112.content:
"Prower!" A voice boomed from the blackened sky as Eric fought his way through robots of Robotnik, gasping for breath as he ran as hard as he could. "I will hunt you down!

Eric didn't know how long he had been going for, the concrete hardened world seemed to go on forever, at least he felt so as he tried to get air in his lungs. Everywhere he went, he would be ambushed by the robots he fought many times over for pratice or while he pretended to be a Freedom Fighter. He could feel his legs burning, his heart bouncing in his chest as he put everything into keeping his feet moving.

He had to keep moving, even though he wasn't sure why, only that it meant his death if he stopped. The trouble came when his foot hit a hole in the ground and he fell hard on it, hearing a loud snap as fire rushed up his leg, screaming in pain briefly. "Come on!" He felt himself scream out in his head, as he got up, trying to ignore the pain in his leg. "Keep going!"

But he was too late.

Eric turned to see what had been chasing him, Robotnik stood in front of him, his eyes budging out as it made a horific laugh that made his ears ring. The fat man then pulled out a remote from his pocket, one that made Eric terrified, the one which his mind turned against him. "You pathetic runt, you don't have the guts to face me, why don't we bring out the real you?"

"Please..." Eric felt himself drop to his knees, begging for Robotnik to change his mind, almost crying as Robotnik almost hit the switch. "Don't...."

Suddenly he screamed out as he felt himself fall, the wind rushing through his hair and clothes, the weight of the world eased up on him before he looked out at his world. He was falling from Robotnik's tower, almost to the soild ground below him that would turn him to paste. Eric tried to move his body but it was as if he was held in place, closing his eyes as he hit the ground...

"Open your eyes."

Eric slowly did as he saw his family home burn in front of him, each member of his family against the side of the house, lifeless. His mother Rosemary staring out at him with a soft smile before timber from the house felt and ignited them. He knelt at the ground as his home turned to a pile of ash, slowly surrounding him, choking him as his world went white, before suddenly it went completely dark.

He realized he was on a street from his time as a thief, his friends Sara, Xin, Zarren, and Tex were off running in front of him, smiling except Xin, generally happy as he tried to stand and follow them. They seemed to go to the guild, a tavern that he called home for years of his life, pushing through the door and beckoning him to come.

Eric push through the door however, and found himself freezing cold before a familar face reached out at him. Frost Lynn then pulled out her sword, pointing it at him like she did in their duel but she was standing with the full army of the Freedom Fighters, all there as he held an unconscious Sally Acorn in one hand and another with a gun pointed right under her chin.

He tried to turn away before he found another flash of light in his eyes and found himself staring at the edge of the Robotnik's tower, Juilan Robotnik gasping for breath as he dangled over the edge from Eric's robotic hand around his neck. The only thing that kept the fat man alive as Eric stared right into Robotnik's eyes. "Eric, this isn't the way." A voice called out to him from his side, the cool, calm voice of Hypon as he stood by Eric and put a hand on his shoulder. "Let him be tried by Mobius, don't let him change you."

"He'll get away!" Eric yelled out, tears rolling down his eyes as he felt the rage in his heart grow, tightening his grip on Robotnik which made him choke out. "He'll get away and I'll be my fault! He'll continue to hurt others, others who don't deserve it!"

"I know you Eric, you want for the pain to stop, his words to no longer affect you. A killer wouldn't care about the lives of others, only his mark. Please, put him down, don't make this mistake. Tails needs you." Hypon tried to calm Eric, seeing the fox cry as they looked out at the whole city. Eric almost felt himself be overcome by the rage just before he saw the same switch in Robotnik's hand as before, only able to mutter out a single word before the fat man hit the button, lost on the wind.

Eric then felt himself scream out as red filled his interface, Overlord stepping in before he could stop it. He felt his hand close around Hypon's neck before it snapped in two, dropping the wolf to the ground as he put Robotnik back into the tower and let him go. Robotnik then sneered before he pointed out the hole and yelled out at him. "Time to get this finished once and for all, kill them all!"

"Yes master." The form that took Eric's body grinned toothily before he swept out of the tower, Eric eyes watched as he killed all of the Freedom Fighters with his own hands, before going before Tails, the last of the whole. He tried to fight the Overlord but it only laughed as it drove a blade through his brother's neck, holding his own brother's body in his arms before Eric regained control and began to sob while the blood soaked around him, in a lake of red as the Freedom Fighters laid around them.

"Oh shut up already." Eric heard his own voice in front of him and looked up to see the Overlord Eric grinned with a bloody knife in his hand, his red interface darker than the blood around them. "The difference between us, is that deep down, you need me. Why you continue to resist me, I will never know, but you just need to tap in on me kid and the world will be ours. I will make your problems, disappear!" Then the Red Eric grabbed him by his hair before putting the blade against Eric's neck, the warmth wetness of the blade only increased his fear as the wild smile the Red Eric turned to hysterical laughing and as it plunged the blade through...

*******

Eric snapped his eyes open as he shot up on his bed, only seeing red before he saw everything normally, realizing his heartbeat was way higher than it should've been. He realized he was gasping for breath and slowly sighed out and started to correct it as he checked his interface.

"Eric?" He heard a soft voice from beside him as Blaze slowly glanced up at him, still half asleep with her head on the pillow, closing her eyes again. "Did it happen again?"

"Y-yeah" He sighed out before he laid back, turning to see her beautiful face before he kissed her forhead. She slowly put her arm around his chest as they held each other, making Eric feel a bit better, though his dreams scared his more than he was willing to admit.

"Go back to sleep, I'll be here for you." Blaze spoke out quietly before he could hear a soft snore, making him realize it was only a few hours before daylight. He slowly closed his eyes and tried to get comfotable before he said one last thing.

"Thank you."

131121.content:
The office of the head shrink was never anyone's favorite visit in the base, most of the people who went in and out typically did it without any choice in the matter, which is how Eric felt as he went to his meeting as Sally required him to. Of course, he didn't actually say anything about his nightmares, or anything at all about himself than surface information that any file would have in spades. The last thing he wanted was to reignite the fear of the Overlord program taking him over, and he knew that not one single person would understand unless it happened to them. He did talk about the abuse he got from those who he was supposed to consider his peers, where they treated him exactly the same as the thugs or monsters they chased outside the walls of the base, which his therapist shrugged and tried to make him consider their fear.

Yeah right... Eric would think as the person chatted away about stress relief practices that he didn't acknowledge. Everyone is afraid of the backstabbing cyborg agent that nearly got Sally and the base captured. It's not the right word. More like they hate me, for being the one who didn't get locked up in their search for justice, the one who got a free pass after letting his old boss run away instead of capturing him, the one who let the war continue instead of ending it when he had the chance.

The blue fox beat himself up about it more than anyone else, how he had planned for years to take down Robotnik, only to watch him fly off. He tried to consider being angry at Hypon for stopping him, as it was only him that kept the fury at bay, but really it was his own choice and Hypon was only doing what he thought was right. Yet it didn't help calm the pain in his heart, which he tried to drown with drink or his nighttime activities, and ended up in worse waters than before. He hardly focused on the head shrink who talked about what they were to cover for the next day, his head already out the door as he body followed, moving along for his steady habit of paperwork to begin for six months.

Eric got looks and grumbles at him in the hall, a steady supply from others, while he made his way to the desk that would sit in Sally's office. She wanted to keep an eye on him and likely wanted to harass him over her own feelings of betrayal, which she claimed to be over, but the cyborg wasn't stupid or unable to see how she frowned when in front of him. With a begrudging sigh, Eric opened the door to see...
131121.title: The Life of a Backstabbing Spy...

choices: Hypon would make time for him, regardless of the fox's wishes
Hypon remained silent and moves to leave the office
Hypon had a few choice words, but left all the same
1311211.content:
Sally's office was as neat and punctual as the squirrel, everything was in the proper place and the appearance was the sort of clear order. The sterile walls and rug of a typical secretary's office were clean and pictures hung of friends or environment shots both before and after the war started. In the side of the room was a small desk that used to hold a rather angry lioness who left with more of a whimper after a certain wolf took matters into her own hands. It would be where he was to set up, although he had his work cut out for him. Eric noticed the rather daunting pile of folders on top of it first before he caught the small chuckle of the wolves on the side of it, in a small embrace while looking into their own eyes. It was coming more common to see the two together, particularly with how playful they seemed to be to wander off for a while, reminding him of the previous relationship Frost had before when it was fresh. Usually he would attempt to be polite and ask them to go somewhere else if they were getting fresh, but he felt tired and didn't want to deal with them at all. So he instead closed the door with a firm thud, watching the Ice Wolf who was pressed against his new desk flinch and pull away to face the noise with a hand on her blade. "Eric! Don't do that again!" Frost exclaimed once she spotted him before giving off a small sigh, fixing her clothes while clearing her throat for being caught off guard.

"If you weren't on my desk, I wouldn't have to. Now if you don't mind, I have work to get done while you two have the time to fool around. Now move." The cyborg fox answered with narrowed eyes at the wolf who was started to blush, moving over to the desk while going past Hypon without acknowledging him. "Well, someone is in a good mood after talking to the therapist... " Frost spoke sarcastically as she made room for the fox to sit at the desk, putting her hands on her hips while Hypon crossed his arms in thought. "Just do your job and be thankful you aren't in a cell or worse..." Eric stared at the wolf who was a bodyguard for Sally decreed by her father before the war, watching her kiss Hypon and motion outside before leaving the two of them alone. Frost had nearly slit his throat once he captured Sally and held her against the others, her loyalty to her friend stronger than most other bonds he had ever seen. It took the combined effort of Hypon and Sonic to yank her off until Sally could order her down, though the potential to continue her efforts always remained in both Frost and Sally if he was to step out of line. Despite the wolf's cold words, he could at least respect her wishes for her friend's safety and how she seemed to help balance Blaze after he was exposed, which was not a simple thing to do.

After a moment, Eric realized Hypon was looking him over in his typical manner of finding answers to questions he didn't already know, turning to match his gaze with a stern and tired question. "Don't you have somewhere else to be?"

13112113.content:
Hypon then let out a response towards Eric, being a little more kind than Frost when it came to formalities, "I do, Eric, but if you would have answered any of my forms of communications; I wouldn't have had to do something of this magnitude to get your attention. We need to talk; even if you feel like we shouldn't and be happy I went with this option before deciding on a messenger whom you may not have wanted to see again. I want to help you but I can't help someone who will not let me in, Eric." Hypon then sighed before turning to face the door, adding as he departed, "You may not agree with my methods or decisions but I chose the greater between two evils. One day you may understand that." With that, Hypon departed with Frost and going down the halls, making his statement loud and clear on where he stood towards Eric's lack of communication with him.

Hypon was a wolf who had connections with several people, organizations, and enough experience to walk in Sally's shoes but didn't want the title of the leader as he never felt worthy of it, rather being a solider or a tactical strategist under her employ. The Night-Blood cared about Eric and was not going to let him destroy his own life just to get some petty vengeance towards a man that everyone wanted dead or apprehended. Hypon had his own stories to tell about that same sentiment towards a full list of others. Killing people would be too easy and Hypon knew that if Eric did what he wanted to Eggman; he would have been changed forever...He was hoping Eric could see past all of that as he helping him from behind the scenes with Sally, unlike Frost who helped him from the inside, handling the relationship with Blaze.

131121132.content:
As Hypon stepped out of Sally's office, he found Frost leaning against the wall on the other side of the hall, likely out of respect for his conversation to remain private. When he motioned for her to follow, they both started to walk down the hall while silently thinking about their encounter with the former secret agent now paying for his crimes. It wasn't long until Hypon's thoughts were interrupted by his partner Frost, speaking low enough for him to hear and no one else in the hall. "I've been taking to Blaze and she told me that he's having nightmares about the old days. Going wild... going after everyone..." After a bit where they reached their newly moved in room, Frost walked in with her Nightblood boyfriend and spoke more directly from her own thoughts while he sat down on their couch. "I know I'm not the best when it comes to technology or dealing with broken trust, but are you sure he won't turn back into that thing? Eric said that he got away with his controller, the one that bends him to his will, shouldn't we be a little more worried?"

When Hypon turned to face her, he could see the topic was bothering her from her feelings towards Sally's safety and knew that she wouldn't ask unless she took the time to think it through. "Tails says it's gone, and I trust his judgement. However, we won't know for sure until Eric runs into him again and is put to the test." He reassured his girlfriend as he stretched out, feeling a small bit of tiredness creep up while he added the small warning.

"Sally won't be happy. She still wants to haul him into our high security prison in case he starts up again, gets a request almost every day from one our fighters, as if she needs more persuasion..." The Ice Wolf interjected before her partner could relax, her own feelings conflicted between friends and loyalties as she sat in one of the other chairs near the couch. "I don't want to say I agree, but I can't imagine leaving the situation alone is good for the health of our cause, especially when it snuck up on us once. It would put people's minds at rest, at the very least."

1311211321.content:
Hypon then calmly responded after moving out of his relaxed state and switching gears to his usual self, "The sacrifice of one for the good will, of many things, only gets people so far in life before they start to nitpick the choices that were made in order to say that he didn't have to die. Just because it is the simple answer doesn't make it the best answer, Frost. Eric seemed completely unaware of the presence of Overlord and that should be no fault of his; not all computers can see every virus hiding in the mainframe. We all have made mistakes, some of them comparable to the drastic events that have occurred but if we threw every single person who has wronged the Fighters; there would be no room for people who actually deserved to be behind bars."

Hypon spoke from a realistic point of perspective, speaking from his memory of being a mercenary and from his experiences in several different organizations; he was going to defend Eric's lack of information at the time of the occurrence and judge him from there, rather than after the fact with what they know now. Overlord had been squashed as they know from Tails' first hand investigation and with it, Eggman's control of the blue fox with a vendetta. Did Hypon agree with everything Eric wanted to do? No, but he was a friend. Hypon was going to make sure that Eric was protected even if he didn't want the protection from him.

Hypon then went back to his relaxed state, adding as he reclined, "But I do agree with one thing, leaving the situation alone is the worst part of this. There are some changes that need to be in play when it comes to the defense of everyone's safety. I will have to speak to Sally about some ideas that have been floating around, but I bet she will be far less happy to see me after all of this..."

13112113212.content:
Eric took a solid breath as he tried to keep his focus on the pile of forms and documents. However he felt his mind drifting away towards anything else, while he leaned back in the uncomfortable chair for a moment, closing his eyes. Doing paperwork wasn't his favorite thing, which was bad enough, until he realized how old much of it was and knew it was pushed on him as a punishment than just business as usual. He was starting to get pretty sick of being treated this way, feeling a small bubbling of anger in his gut while he glanced at his boss' room, letting his annoyance paint the door where the squirrel was inside. She came in a few moments after the two wolves left, giving him orders to keep pace with the paperwork while she went inside her private room for a call, which annoyed and made Eric curious. Even though he was no longer a spy in an offical sense, he couldn't help himself from being kept out of the loop, as it had always put him into a bind when he didn't know the cards already in play.

It wasn't hard for him to hear what was going on behind the door. Once a upon a time his robotic and normal ears were trained to detect even the most subtle of sounds such as tumblers in a safe or the most silent of talking. If he could see someone's lips, he could tell most of the time what was said even from a distance, however, his ears could still detect the pitch and pronunciation of letters from close by. So he tapped the sensors in his arm and dragged his finger over the sensitivity until he could make out the half of Sally's conversation on the phone. "-and... I know you need help Lupe... the betrayal hurt us. I can't spare one fighter... the fox caused us damages we are still trying to repair, no way of knowing how much he could still do... Yes... I don't want to talk about what he might know about me. It makes my skin crawl Lupe, you know that... Not to my knowledge, but his brother says it's safe for now... Just do what you can..."

The cyborg fox could feel the frown on his face as he fixed his ear to normal ranges, regretting his choice to spy on the squirrel, but was also rather angry from what he heard. Clearly Sally didn't bury any of her feelings, but the edge in her voice hurt as much as it showed how much she truly felt about him. Eric let off a sigh as he made his robotic hand start to file papers while he thought, trying to balance his state of mind without making a scene with his boss. It was true he had gathered a wide array of information on Sally before they had even met, and he developed feelings for her when he was younger as it was hard not to see the woman behind the throne. He knew just about everything he could want to know about her, from her past to more recent things, but it was mostly for his task of capturing her for Robotnik. Sally however saw all of what he held about her when Tails plugged him in to erase Overlord from his system, understandably freaking out over things he had thought or pictured about her while he was dealing with his younger demons. Eric had apologized countless times for it, but that would never erase it from her mind, even though he only cared for Blaze in that way now. What made him mad was treating him like he was on a timer before causing another incident and treating him like a creep for how he had felt as a teenager, which hurt what remained of his pride after everything that happened.

"It's not like you don't have the same thoughts for Sonic, even if he sleeps with every girl on base before seeing you Princess..." Eric mutter out sarcastically as he thought, followed with a bitter taste left on his tongue from the words. He never got mad at Cream for delivering the news but it made Hypon think that Sally was using the child as a shield after the fifth time it had occurred and that was what really bothered him. Sally had other ways to message him and several other messengers but she always chose Cream, the person he treated as a daughter to him. He didn't know if it was just fate, Cream's request, or just Sally trying to get under his skin but he never really thought about it until this time.

Hypon didn't know what the talk could be about as there was a long list of things but the first thing that quickly came to mind was Eric and Overlord as since he has been involved with both sides of the same coin since the night he stopped Eric from making a bad decision. He was also there with Sally and saw all of Eric's demons painted on the screen when the erasing was happening. If there was a long list of reasons why he chose to defend Eric even after all the stuff happened and how he has been treated, the top of the list would simply read, "Eric Prowler is the victim, not the monster." He didn't change how he felt towards the Blue Fox but Hypon wanted to avoid touching any open wounds with his friend unless he wanted to talk about it, taking a more subtle approach than being the doctors and play 20 questions with the mentally scarred fox.

The lone wolf walked the halls towards Sally's office, his mind deep within thought about what the conversation was going to be this time. Sally and Hypon had the moments of agreeableness in the past but they usually fought, never really seeing eye to eye on anything. Most days Hypon felt like he was talking to a wall and Sally saw a fighter who was high on their own horse but they both had experiences with the world so they still continued to talk, even if the talking sounded like a courtroom drama. 13112113212122.content:
Hypon looked at Sally before finally letting out a simple question, asking as a friend more than a member of the Fighters, "Are you sure that this is what you want, Sally?"

Sally looked determined back towards the Nightblood, knowing that he was trying to read her since there many encounters in the past, speaking firmly towards him, "Yes. This is what I want. This is what is best for everyone's protection."

Hypon then retorted, "Even Eric's Protection? Because from my viewpoint Sally, this is protecting everyone expect him."

Sally then stood up to answer back, "Would you rather our enemies have the upper hand while we are weaken after what had happened to us?"

Hypon, remaining seated, looked directly at the squirrel and answered simply, "Sally, you are deflecting the real question here and proving my point here." Sally crossed her arms as the wolf continued, "I am speaking as your friend here but you need to rethink your decision towards Eric. Asking me and his brother to do this is going to make an enemy out of the one person you don't need to. Put yourself in his shoes for a moment and be reasonable here or better yet; walk a mile in mine..."

Sally then threatened, "You don't understand how much pressure I have been dealing with so don't treat me like one of your 'subjects'. I am your boss, not your experiment. I have to make the tough choices here so don't you dare play the high and mighty card on me."

Hypon then sighed before getting up, "Your 'decisions' may reveal more things that you may not want to know...especially after the last time." Hypon wasn't able to continue after feeling a very hard smack connect with his face from Sally. Sally knows what Hypon was insinuating and was having none of it as she added, "Don't...you...dare mention that again in my presence..." Hypon's mood remained firm as he looked at Sally, adding, "All I am saying is to give him a chance to redeem himself; like you gave to me. This isn't the first time that we've been attacked on the inside. The AFF tried to frame me for the last attack and you listened to reason. What's so hard in giving him the same chance for basically the same thing? You and I both know that he was not in control at the time and it's not his fault that he did not know about the plans that Eggman laid out for it."

Sally and Hypon were basically having a shouting match at this point, louder than their usual ones as Hypon tried to defend Eric while Sally wanted Eric to come clean about details. Hypon could only wonder what was going through the mind of the blue-tailed fox outside...

After a while of pointless shouting and constantly circling; Sally then asked firmly, "Enough of the stalling, I want an answer now, Hypon."

Hypon then turned his back towards Sally and walked to the door, giving his answer without looking at her, "There are several things that we agree on Sally and even parts of this is included in that discussion but I will not be a part of removing pieces of someone's memory without their actual consent. You may be the leader of the fighters but you are not the person with that authority. Rethink your decison...then we will talk." With that, Hypon made his exit, choosing the lesser of two evils; agreeing with half of the problem but not the methods on how to solve it. He glanced at Eric as he entered the waiting room, hoping he heard everything as he made his exit outside the office entirely without looking back. He made his choice and was about to inform the one person who needed to know what was coming if he didn't already know about Sally's plans.

131121132121222.content:
Sally was about to go after Hypon for what he said, furious at how he treated her less like the leader of the Freedom Fighters and more like a recruit doing something stupid, yet the cyborg fox stood in front of the hallway door blocking her. At first the squirrel was about to shove him away, but the fox raised his arm out in order to keep her at a distance. "Out of my way Prower! That wolf doesn't get to walk away from me after talking like that!" However Eric just stood and stared at his boss without saying a word at first, but slowly started to speak from what he heard and his own thoughts.

"What did you say to me when I was given my title as Freedom Fighter Sally?" When he didn't hear a reply and was shoved once more, Eric continued with a low tone. "You said that 'a Freedom Fighter should always fight for those who cannot fight for themselves, to aid those who are the most harmed under the hand of our enemy, to guide those who are lost back to the light of salvation.' I may have been a spy at the time, but even I won't forget those words. You have, haven't you?"

The former princess however just shouted back at him, feeling the fury in her chest explode in the form of mocking laughter as she jabbed a finger in his chest. "You're innocent?! You?! Our people were captured because of you, turned into slaves! Our base nearly was captured by that scumbag and I was held hostage by you! Every single person here and the war was at risk of a fate worse than death and it was because you put it in jeopardy!"

"Fuck you Sally! Don't you dare put all of that on me!" The cyborg fox snarled, scaring the squirrel who took a step back with a frightened look on her face. He continued without hesitation as he finally could speak his mind without a filter, his tone sharp, but slowly calming down as he stepped towards her. "I am SO sorry for putting your people on the line, and I know I made you uncomfortable with my file on you, but stop treating me like I'm going to turn on you and stop wishing I didn't come back from that tower." When Sally tried to step in and argue the point to regain control, Eric shut her down immediately. "No! You don't understand what it was like being his prisoner! You got away with your friends and could play soldier in the forrest, I was there for YEARS! I didn't have any friends, I only had HIM and his goons for company. The few people I did know after I tried to escape turned me over to save themselves, then Robotnik made me watch my family being killed as punishment for leaving him! I didn't know it was fake until Tails stood in front of me that day, I though they were gone forever because of me!"

Sally bumped back into the side of the desk as Eric stood a foot away from her, alarmed at being alone without any backup, right as she was snapped back to the fox in front of her. "What do you do when you don't have anyone or anything left Sally? When everything you knew and everyone you had were gone because of your actions?" She could see tears slide down the side of his face as he stood there, feeling the weight of his words between them. "I never wanted to be his agent, he wasn't my proud mentor, he was worse than a monster and I tried like hell to break free well before the attack. His 'Overlord' program is the worst kind of control Sally, every thought and action was filtered, at points I had no option but to obey under threat of my system overheating and exploding or him taking direct control and causing a bloody rampage. Everyone here was always painted an enemy because I didn't have the freedom to think otherwise, they were just objects in my path to get to you."

The two stood quietly for a moment, sharing the first look at each other since the day Eric stood on stage to accept his membership to be a Freedom Fighter, before he spoke for the last time. "I'm not innocent by any stretch, but I could never fight for myself before my chains were removed by Tails. Why did you think I went to confront Robotnik once I was free? I went to finally get him for what he did to me since I was a kid, taken from my family and forced to be his slave. Now I am as free as I can be from him and I want to earn my path back to the light. All I ask is to be given a fair chance, for you to respect that I'm trying not to be the same person and it's hard to change so quickly." The cyborg took a breath once he aired the bubbling anger in his gut, knowing that there was no way for him to return to work after what happened, so he went back to his room and left Sally alone with what had been said by them. He hoped she could give him a chance to do better, but did quietly acknowledge that he worried about being a risk to the cat he had feelings for as well as his brother if Overlord wasn't through, since it would go after them first.

Blaze did not look pleased at Eric as her purple robe and white pants were wrinkled, most likely while she slept waiting for him to be released, and her gaze was focused square into his eyes. Eric quickly found himself looking away from her as her gaze felt like she was staring daggers at him, silently telling him off while they were in public, as he softly walked until he was next to her. *****

Eric tried not to let fear control him as whenever Blaze was quiet was when she was mostly likely to go off, and past experience told him not to push it. Despite his fear, Eric also felt tired as they past by store after store, watching Blaze and remembering how beautiful she looked, even when totally upset at him. He was reminded of old memories, how they went out and how she stuck with him even after he put a gun right against Sally's head and almost let Robotnik beat the Freedom Fighters.

Blaze however noticed him watching her and didn't say a word until they pulled up to the base, parking in her spot, she stared at Eric and for a few more minutes before she spoke. " You promised me that you were turning over a new leaf."

"Oh clearly! Staying in a cell all night after you get so drunk you can't even handle three officers, something we both know you could do if you weren't beating yourself up." Blaze quipped as Eric stared out the window, slowly putting a hand on his shoulder. "Look, I know you care about that old man for what he did for you back then, but Sally is looking for excuses to put you in a high- security cell for life after you nearly took us down. This is about survival, cut the Thief Lord loose with your condolences, or you will not as useful to him for much longer."

She then followed him into the base, keeping flames from forming in her hands, knowing she had to keep a strong head for the both of them.

1331.content:
There is an art to computer hacking and protection from others, it takes a keen creative mind and a lot of layers of shells that are too hard to crack. Since he had spent years breaking down their firewalls, laying snoopers and generally making their tech go against them, he was ironically the best one to head the former cyber protection unit. He however had them reassigned to grunt work when it was clear he was several pages above them and they were just there for general warning only, which didn't help his social life.

Eric sat in front of the mainframe for the whole base set-up, computing codes that were to replace the old ones, while also keeping an eye on security feeds. Sally was less than happy he got a huge role in their defense, but he proved to strengthen the base and not be a hinderance so she let it slide while having weekly check ins so he didn't muck around. He heard a bell ring and he glanced over to the feed which had Sally standing outside his door, waiting impatiently for him to open the door, the angle giving him a view down her jacket. He however hit a switch and watched Sally disappear before she reappeared behind him, looking at all of his work as he spun around to face her.

"What is your progress Prower?" She asked as she looked around accusingly for something to yell at him about, however Eric just cleared his throat and let the boredom ring from his voice.

"Well, I'm working. You guys needed to check on your security more often, this stuff is behind compared to some of the stuff Robotnik had. Rewriting codes is going to take a while more."

Sally stared at him with disbelief as her hands went to her hips. "You've had months! What are you up to!?"

"Look, it's not like I can copy and paste new code in. I have to literally break up sections and change it bit by bit, and you should be glad." Eric tried to explain as he glared through her stares, turning the screen so she could see his work. "Right now, it would take a supercomputer to hit us in order to break into this base's files."

"So? That sounds like what we had before."

Eric shook his head and ran his hand through his hair. "Maybe five years ago, but now you can almost compete with something brand new. Trust me though, I'm not done yet."

From this Sally stomped her boot into the ground and pointed a finger at his head. "WHAT?! How much longer could this take?"

"Maybe another month. Then the base will be years ahead of hackers, which is a slight advantage. Once I do a test hack and can't get in on the first try, you should be good to go."

Eric watched as Sally cooled off and slowly brought herself to speak again, this time barely holding back her annoyance. "You better have it done by next month." He watched he head off and close the door behind herself as she went to her office, slowly spinning back into place.

"Man... I miss the days where I was the one barking orders to Sleet and Dingo. Not that they listened much, but having a boss who hates you sucks." He spoke to himself as he leaned back and rested his head on his hands. "Of course I was the brainwashed minion of a sociopathic narcissist, but at least he gave me vacation days. Plus a gun and went on ops several times a week, now I'm luckly if the display in the war room is glitching so I can fix it."

"You have given her plenty to be upset with you about. That file of her on your hardrive she saw when dumping out your whole system of surpises didn't help. Plus when you put a gun to her head and threatened to kill her, that steamed her up bad..."

Eric sighed as started to work again, suddenly in a sour mood as he worked on the codes, while his A.I. went on about his mistakes. Not wanting to have this argument again when someone could come knocking and hear it, having to explain yet again how he wasn't crazy and he was just talking to his system. "I said I was sorry and that it was just my prgraming, not to mention the hundreds of times I said I was sorry for that file! I dumped it as well as Overlord, not like I feel the same way about her. I really like Blaze."

"Jury's out on that kiddo. I saw you eyeing her as she left, don't forget we share a head and an eye." Eric's systems chirped on as his rested his head on his desk and groaned at how annoyingly accurate his new head was.

"Life is pain, highness. Anyone who says differently is selling something..." William Goldman from the Princess Bride

Her entire life was a balance of expectations and routines, one after the other. From punching the ancient oak tree bark to strengthen her hands and feet, running for miles and sparring constantly with the tribe's boys, she was in the best condition for her age of nine. In her tribe, there was no exceptions once a child was able to walk and talk, you did whatever work needed to be done. Being the daughter of the chief, she was expected to be the highest standard for all of the tribe, and Frost took great lengths to be her father's example. Frost had spent years studying the ancient texts of their past, learning to hunt for food and resources in the forest with the hunters, and learning how to fight anyone and win. Yet her efforts were never treated as enough, her father always had more to give her and she did her best to finish what she started, but occasionally she wondered about her father's motivation.

And wonder she did as she went through the forest trees, her tribal cloth covering around her blue fur and her sandals moving through the rough soil. She was on her way to meet a someone, her prize hung on her waist, a brand new short sword that her mentor Aaron gave her as she put a few claws through her soft long hair in order to put it into a ponytail. She could hear the sound of the river stream, trickling down the hill, anxious to show off her prize when she stopped a few feet from the stream path, suddenly aware of a pair of eyes trained on her. Her hand went to her sword hilt, when she felt a breeze by her head and raised an arm to catch a soild kick that would've spun her head around. Frost then blocked several other attacks using her arms and shins to absorb the blows, before she grabbed one of her attacker's arms and flipped them over her shoulder, getting on top of them while pinning their arms to the ground with a smile on her face. "Nice try Sammy." Frost playfully commented to her attacker, who in the sunlight was a lioness with an equally playful grin on their face.

"That's what you think." She smirked before she kissed Frost's cheek, starling the ice wolf until she felt something furry wrap around her bare waist. Before she could react, she found herself face first into the dirt with her arm pulled behind her back, the lioness letting out a small laugh as she sat on her back. "Aren't you the one always telling me not to let my guard down? You should learn from your example."

Frost however did not worry as she used strength to push off from the ground, the lioness startled with an eep as she was tossed off and Frost grabbed her arms, putting them up above their faces as she again rested on top of the lioness. "You were saying Samantha?"

Samantha did a small pout but grew a smile as Frost let go and helped her back up, both of them brushing off dirt from their fur. "Ha, still the best. I thought you would forget about my tail, but nice job with countering my counter." They both sat down by the stream and dipped their bare feet into the water, feeling the cool refreshing water as it drifted by. "Nice new hardware Frosty, you must be proud reaching warrior status."

"I worked hard to get this far." Frost answered back with a grin, although she felt embarrassed about the kiss since Samantha had used it to trick her. "Speak of hard work, how is working with your dad at his forge?"

The lioness kicked over a stone with her toe, but answer in a normal tone. "It's rough, but I'm better than I was before. It takes a lot on my arms, and my hands always need attention when work is over, but I'm not quiting. My dad wants me with him, every since Mom died, he wants to be closer to me so I don't feel lonely."

"Hey, I'm here for you. No matter what, I'll be there." Frost reassured Samantha, but felt herself grow a little more serious with her friend, a dark scowl forming on her face. "I understand, ever since Asher died, my dad has been trying to keep me too busy to think about it."

Samantha got quiet as she thought back to when the news hit that Asher Lynn was killed in an ambush, how it shocked everyone to the core when a signs that a rival clan of Night-Bloods were suspects of the attack that left their once soon-to-be hero with many stabs to the back years ago. "No one saw it coming, my dad said that we used to be friendly with the Night-Bloods, now they're little more than a memory."

"Good riddance!" The ice wolf next to her exclaimed, the wound not healed as her friend had expected. "Those traitorous back-stabbing monsters deserved what they got! My father did our clan proud when he lead the attack on that village of theirs, wiping everyone out!"

The lioness worried about her friend's anger, putting her hand on Frost's cheek getting Frost's attention of her worried expression. "Frost, you don't mean that... they were just like us."

"They stopped being like us when they murdered my older brother." Frost countered sharply, standing up abruptly, when her closest friend just watched her, the ice wolf let out a small sigh. "I-I'm sorry Sam, I've ruined our moment together, maybe we should meet tomorrow at the forge. I'll try to be in a better mood."

Samantha just stood up and hugged Frost, pulling back on the hug to kiss her lips softly, turning the ice wolf's cheek red as she pulled away. "I hope so, maybe we could talk about lighter things, like the shade of your fur when I mess with you. Just try to keep positive, and cool it when you get those thoughts. Just think of me and it will be better." She smiled as she patted Frost's cheek and ran off in the direction of the village, leaving the ice wolf wide eyed and with a goofy smile.

She knows me too well. Frost thought as she felt her heart slowly start to calm down from the workout it got when Samantha kissed her. She then moved in the direction of the village, going to see her father to show him her new sword and rank, hoping he would be proud of her and not question what she was doing out in the forest.
142.title: The Story of "Frost" Lynn, a tribal wol...

Dinner with the Ox and Ice Wolves
1421.content:
Living with the chief of the village has it's perks, as Frost lived in the largest house at the center of the village, while the rest lived in smaller homes. Each home was based on the weath of the family, a mix of straw was for the poor homes, wood for the stable homes, and metal which was for the ones who could afford to maintain it. Her home was most wood and reinforced with metal supports, one of the few second-story homes in the village, yet the best looking and well managed of them all. Elaborate patterns and pictures were painted to explain their history to the outlooker, but only the Keeper of History would tell those who proved themselves.

Frost stood outside the door to her home, feeling a bit hesitant to go in as she was half-expecting trouble by her father, yet swallowing her concern to push the curtain away and went in. Her home's interior was decorated to honor past chiefs, weapons and other relics were scattered along the walls, each with their own story that she knew by heart. As she made her way through the foyer, she saw the curtain for her father's room and saw the flicker of light from under it, leading her to it as she called out into the room. "May I enter father?"

"Yes, daughter." The deep voice of her father rang out from inside, letting her enter and kneel before to show respect to him. As she looked up and saw his grizzled blue fur covered by the fur robe he wore like his father and the one before, seeing that he was looking at a painting of Asher done years ago while a candle was lit on his desk. It pained Frost that her father spent so much time staring at the face of his son, when it only made him angry of what happened. As she thought, he turned to face her, his eyes sharp and his focus on her, something that made her shiver as he was a force to be under as he towered over her. "I see that Whiteclaw gave you the sword."

"Yes father." Frost replied quickly as she unhooked it from her side and held it up so he could examine it. "I fought until he had no choice but to award me the prize. I am now a warrior like you and grandfather before us."

Her father picked up the sword and pulled it from it's sheath, holding it to the light before returning it to his daughter. " It will suite you well as you work, now go and clean up, we are expecting guests tonight."

"Guests?" Frost asked as she rose from her place, hooking her sword back on her hip, unaware what her father was talking about and a bit hurt that he did not offer her praise for all of her hard work. "You did not mention we were hosting."

Her father stared her down until she looked away before responding. "I wasn't aware I had to tell you anything daughter, I do not need your approval to do my work as chief. The only reason I mentioned it is that you need to be formal for this dinner, so get a bath and dress in the gown your mother prepared. We are playing host to the Ox clan, with their leader and wife coming for dinner, as well as their son."

Frost frowned as the Ox leader's son was a notorious jerk like his father and was a handful of years older than her. Even with the visitors, she had a bone to pick with another thing her father mentioned. "I'm wearing a gown? Dad, why can't I wear something else? The Ox clan aren't too picky with what they wear, why can't I go to dinner like this?"

"Because you need to look good for your suitor. Even he will be dressed formally as for the traditions of our tribe. Of course you will marry once you are older, but the marriage will lead to great trade and improved relationships."

Frost sighed and frowned as this was one part of her responsibilities as the daughter of the chief, to marry off to someone she never met or cared about for the benefits to her tribe. Even though she had argued with her father for the last few months about the topic, he was content with sending her off. He seemed to laugh when she suggested that she should lead the tribe in his place, her father arguing that all other clans and tribes were led by men, and a female leader would spell weakness in his opinion. When she tried to compare herself with her brother Asher, who also was groomed for chief at her age, her gender seem to convince her father otherwise despite her skills that were equal to Asher at her age. Frost had another problems to this role that she was expected to play, firstly, she could no longer fight or hunt to provide for the tribe which made her angry since it was her life. Secondly, she would be expected to have children and one of her children had to be a boy in order to lead the tribe after her father, where he would take a role she could fill on her own if her father allowed her.

This led to her final problem, that she had no intention of having children with a boy. She had none of the feelings that other girls her age had about the boys of the tribe, the only person she had feelings and cared for was Samantha. According to her friend, her feelings were normal, but her tribe was very traditional and such acts were highly discouraged, so they met in private to talk. Frost wanted to talk about her father about how she truely felt, but with the stress of her other issues with him and how traditional he tried to hold her, she kept quiet. One other girl who expressed similar feelings was exiled to the woods away from the tribe, along with her close friend. So Frost was more than hesitant to admit anything, for her safety and of Samantha's.

"You must behave for dinner, your mother and I are using your real name, so no nonsense tonight." Her father spoke as if she didn't have a choice when she moved to leave the room, but the rigidness of her own tone made him sigh.

"I will only answer to Frost, and if we are showing them the true us, my 'suitor' should see what he will get.."

"Tara, the name your mother and I gave you is far more beautiful, it's symbolism of your birth will be more attractive to the Ox's than 'Frost'. I know that your brother gave you that nickname for your powers but please humor us."

"No." Frost growled as she left, leaving her father's room frigid and freezing the flame of the candle in mid-flicker.

Her father equally growled in annoyance that his daughter was being so frustrating, but understood that like the rest of her family, she had grown up much too soon from the death of her brother. He peeled away the ice flame as the temperature grew back to normal, turning to shout up hall as his daughter made it to the stairs."Fine! But in exchange your mother will put makeup on you, and do your hair when she gets back!"

"Fine!" Frost yelled back as she stormed up the stairs, willing to deal in order to hold her ground. She could already tell that tonight was going to be very unconfortable for her and her family, as the Ox tribe were always war-hungry and they were used to getting what they wanted, by force if it was possible. She remembered the Ox clan leader's son's name was Dante, and that he liked to mess with her by making her look stupid, something that was stopped by Asher in the past. She felt like punching him in the face the next time she saw him, but she was willing to try and play nice, at least so when the two of them are alone, she could explain why she was not a good choice and he could convince his father to drop it.

Then again... she had higher hopes to rule the world than for that plan to go smoothly...

14211.content:
"I look like an idiot."

Frost commented as she stared into a mirror, watching the reflection of her mother Rebecca work on her hair while staring at her own look. Her gown that she was to wear was traditional, a pale buckskin gown that covered most of her body to her ankles and a pair of beaded moccasins to cover her feet.

"You look like a beautiful young woman." Her mother's gentle voice spoke behind Frost's head, braiding her long hair into two long braids that would rest over her shoulders. Frost watched the red fur of her mother's hands work through her hair with practice, a sour look on her own face. This had been their progress once Frost had stepped out of her bath and was given the gown. She disliked dresses and gowns alike, the simple breechcloth that most children her age wore was so much more functional. Frost had not figured out a way to fight in a dress without giving up her speed or flexibility, but apparently others had before her somehow. As for braided hair, when she ran it always smacked against her, so she prefered her hair to be free or in a simple ponytail. A last, she still had to honor her deal, though she had other reasons to be alone with her mother.

"Mom, can I ask you something?"

"Yes dear?" Rebecca answered as she finished one braid and worked on the other, her red fur glowing in the candlelight, as well as her gentle yet sharply toothed smile.

"Did you have to do this for Dad?"

Her mother laughed before she answered, the amusement in her voice was hard to miss. "Oh yes, I did indeed! My mother helped me just the same, but I'll never forget how uncomfortable your father looked in his clothes, like he'd rather be somewhere else than sitting at the table with his parent's and my family! Of course, back then, I was known to be quite aware how to twist a boy around my finger..."

"Mom!" Frost exclaimed with reddening cheeks with embarrassment as her mother chuckled, and finished up her last braid.

"You'll figure it out in time, it's how they act around you. The same goes for you, they can tell if you mean what you say or if it's all hot air. The trick is to balance it in your favor, just enough so they are guessing and want to learn more."

Frost thought about what her mother said and wondered if that's how Samantha played with her, drawing some parallels between the two. She then decided to test how correct her worries were about her feelings for Samantha from her families perspective by asking her mother a direct question. "Mom... if a girl likes...another girl, is that consider wrong??

"Of course not! I liked many girls that were at your age, we liked the same things and they grew to be my friends. They are the best friends I ever hoped to have, although I don't agree with all of their choices in life, I will always care for them and like them for our time together." Rebecca answered back calmly as she sat with her daughter, although Frost frowned as her mother misinterpreted what she had asked.

"No Mom, I meant... in the love way. Is it wrong for a girl to love another girl? To... have feelings above companionship?"

"In the love way..." Her mother repeated as face hardened in thought, making Frost's heart beat faster as she hoped that she was wrong about her thoughts, until she heard her mother's soft voice. "I don't believe so, although your father believes that it is. He holds to the notions that men and women are only meant to be together from the ancient texts in order to continue the tribe's lineage, and that disrupting this balance puts others at risk in the tribe. But it is never that simple in my option, the heart wants what it wants, who are we to judge why a woman or a man should be with somone simular?" Rebecca then knelt in front of Frost and gripped Frost's hands, looking gently into her daughter's eyes. "I'm not sure why you ask dear, is something on your mind? You can talk to me..."

Frost felt her body go numb as she was at the point where her next words would decide if she would be rejected or accepted as how she felt. Her heart couldn't stop from beating like a drum as her secret held in was about to be revealed. She thought carefully about her choice of words as her mother moved to face her daughter, a concerned look on her face for what seemed to bother her so much. "Mom... I really don't like-"

"Frost, Rebecca dear! Our guests have arrived, come down and greet them!"

Both Rebecca and Frost heard the the shouting from the door, but Rebecca simply held her daughter in place, not through with what she wanted her to hear. "What Tara? You don't like what?"

"Ladies, please come and say hello! Our guests have come a long way and deserve the courtesy of a greeting before we began arranging the plans for the better future of our tribes!"

The young ice wolf just sighed however, lowering her head as she realized that her fate was already decided by her father, and just spoke in a low tone. "It... It doesn't matter how I feel. Let's just go down and get this done already Mother."

Rebecca was rather worried at what seemed to hurt her daughter so much, but let go of her hands and watched her leave the room. She had never seen her daughter look so down, and as she followed after her, she was already thinking about their conversation and what it had to do with her interupted statement.
